fields.description:
In the "Commit" view for a Git repository in SourceTree, files in the "Unstaged files" panel appear to be sorted in a random or undefined order, rather than being sorted alphabetically or by folder. For example, the unstaged files list might look like this:


{code:java}
src/com/mycompany/myapp/Main.cs
fonts/MyFont1.ttf
src/addons/polarityreverser/ReversePolarity.cs
src/com/mycompany/myapp/Window.cs
fonts/AnotherFont.otf
fonts/OneMoreFont.otf
src/com/mycompany/myapp/Settings.cs

{code}

making it annoyingly difficult to stage all of the files in a specific folder at the same time. Worse, each time you stage a file, the order *changes*.

Files should be sorted alphabetically by folder, and the order should never change.
fields.summary: Files in "Unstaged files" panel are arranged in random order

fields.description:
Suppose I have searched for a particular change and located it in the search pane. I can "view in full log" but if it was a long time ago it is hard to trace it forward and figure out which branches have this change (or whether some later change has removed it). I would like more help tracking down why a fix is not present in a particular branch.
Some ideas:
- A command (or even a column in the search window) that tells me whether a particular change has been merged into the current branch (i.e., it's somewhere in the ancestors of the current branch tip).
- A command that looks at a particular hunk and shows a list (or tree diagram?) of all the branches it has been merged into.
- A command on a hunk that tells me the status of this hunk in the current branch. This would show me the chain of commits by which it was merged into my current branch, if it has been (or tell me it has not); it would also show any later commits that have modified this same region of code.
fields.summary: Allow tracing a hunk through future history

fields.description:
Disable/Hide from menu "Remove Ctrl+Del"

Reason - "Remove" very near "Discard"
 
Real situation
1. Big project without source control
2. Create new repository in project folder
3. By terminal add all *.cs files "git add *.cs"
4. Сheck staged files see many temporary *.cs 
5. Select all staged files
6. Click "Remove" instead "Discard" - Yes
7. .... I lost big project sources

I think remove files or disable by default or delete file to Recycle Bin.

Thanks.
fields.summary: "Remove Ctrl+Del" Disable/Hide from menu or delete in Recycle Bin

fields.description:
Hi,

When I click the "Check Remote Status":
* it has no effect if I cannot authenticate (1),
* it has no effect if I can authenticate, but if there is nothing new on the remote (2).

By _no effect_, I mean no visual feedback on the UX. Nothing just happen from the user's point of view.

I'd expected either a:
* "Sorry, cannot reach the remote, authentication failed" for (1), _or_ a
* "Nothing new, buddy, you're on top" for (2).

What do you thing about it?
fields.summary: No feedback on Check Remote Status when not able to authenticate

fields.description:
Hi,

I just updated to SourceTree 1.6.24.  Earlier in the day I was using two separate accounts (VSO and GitHub) with no problem.  Just a few minutes ago I updated to 1.6.24 after seeing a prompt and immediately, when I tried to push to my GitHub repository, I got authentication failure.

I tried various ways of authentication short of setting up an SSH key.  Personal Access Tokens didn't work and my normal password didn't work.  Further, my VSO account kept prompting me for my password, seemingly unprompted (I was working in a GitHub repository).

I noticed on my GitHub account that it reported several failed logins.  Reverting to 1.6.23 fixed everything.

fields.description:
h4. Problem
After upgrading to SourceTree 1.6.24, BitBucket Cloud and BitBucket Server authentication fails with saved credentials and entering the correct password does not get accepted either.

h4. Workaround
Downgrade and install SourceTree 1.6.23 (or an earlier version): [http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/sourcetree/windows/SourceTreeSetup_1.6.23.exe].

h4. Workaround 2
As a temporary workaround copying the attached  [^Askpass.exe.config] file in to
{{C:\Program Files (x86)\Atlassian\SourceTree}} (or the installation folder respectively).

This will provide the necessary configuration and should fix the multiple authentication requests.
fields.summary: Cannot push in 1.6.24 due to authorization error

fields.description:
I often clone new repos and want to organize them into bookmark folders.  

Right now this is two steps: create the bookmark folder before cloning, then clone (or vice versa, clone to root folder, then make the bookmark folder and move the repo into it).

It'd be nice to be able to do both in the clone dialog.

Even nicer would be to allow some sensible defaults to be specified.  eg, if cloning from github.com/foo/bar, I would put this "bar" repo into a folder github/foo.  This could be guessed or configured.
fields.summary: When cloning a repo, provide the ability to specify a new bookmark folder.

fields.description:
In a large Enterprise environment is preferable to be able to set certain options for a team such as:
* Defaults for repository locations
* Configuration for pushing and pulling options (upstream)
* Defaults for third party app defaults (such a Diff options like KDiff)

Currently, there is a user configuration file in this location:
C:\Users\mperonto\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree.exe_Url_<<randomid>>\<<versionid>>\user.xml

This file is difficult to match with GroupPolicy to set team-specific defaults and settings.
It would be good to provide an override file in a location like this:
C:\Users\mperonto\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\settings.xml

Ideally some this could be used for both *defaults* and *enforcing* some team settings.

*Alternatives*
* Place these kind of settings in the Windows registry
* Build an integration with Bitbucket and allow Bitbucket to control SourceTree settings.
fields.summary: Team settings defaults and overrides for enterprise settings

fields.description:
When I type some text in the commit comment area in Korean language, only English is typed.
I can type Korean only after I move focus to another application or click on the windows taskbar.
fields.summary: Cannot input text in Korean language in the commit comment area

fields.description: When I opened the source tree there was a error. When I tried to open it again it worked fine but all tab with each project was closed except one which was selected as the last. Anyway I'm attaching the log for this issue.
fields.summary: Error when I opened the source tree

fields.description:
In the main tree view, the bottom of the text is clipped:

!image-2015-11-23-15-52-40-900.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: At 4K resolution on windows 7, the text is clipped

fields.description: When trying to push a commit that is not fully created (means it's commiting currently) SourceTree doesn't responds any more and has to be crashed manually,
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when pushing a commit while it's commiting

fields.description: Using SourceTree default, I currently have 25 projects in my repository listing and since they're ordered by the order they are added, makes it difficult to find a project.  A search box and/or filter options would be great!
fields.summary: Search In Repository Panel

fields.description: Just when I've tried to create a pull request from sourcetree to our BitBucket Server it crash.
fields.summary: Crash on create pull request

fields.description: When reporting SRCTREEWIN-3915 I noticed JIRA listed my version which I looked up through the SourceTree about box as unreleased, But I was provided with the update 2 days ago IIRC.
fields.summary: 1.6.23 is listed as unrelease version

fields.description:
Git terminal does not open from SourceTree toolbar anymore and gives the following error message:

Error encountered
It has not been possible to start the Git Bash terminal.

When I manually start my Git Bash (since I use and have used System) I am able to navigate and operate on the same repository.

It seems independant of which repository I have selected/opened. Git Terminal fails to start,
fields.summary: Git terminal (system) does not start after update to 1.6.23.0

fields.description:
I often deal with large-ish files in git. By large, I mean it takes >30 seconds to push/pull any changes. (definition of large depends on connection speed)

When pushing/pulling large changes to repositories, the interface looks like it isn't doing anything and I've canceled the progress only to find out it was working and had almost finished downloading the changes.

I'd like to see a progress bar similar to Tortoise git's on push/pull that actually matches the data transfer progress.
fields.summary: Show progress bar on push/fetch

fields.description:
click 'Open current version' on a folder, not a file. The app crashes

note: my app says it's v 1.6.23.0 though in your tracking system it's an unreleased SourceTree version
fields.summary: App crash: log history, context menu, click "open current version" for a folder

fields.description:
I am able to drag and drop columns in commit view and also able to change width of columns. This feature is however pretty useless as it keeps resetting to default state and not only after closing and reopening the project but also after simple tab switch.
We have quite a wide commit graph and the column is too narrow. I have to keep adjusting its width all the time and it is pretty annoying.
fields.summary: Columns in main commit view don't should remember width and position

fields.description:
I downloaded the setup "SourceTreeSetup_1.6.23.exe" from the atlassian website.
The installation process with administrator rights works fine (shows no error).
I configured the openSSH Client and my id_rsa file.
If I start the software now I'll get an error:
---------------------------
Ein Fehler ist aufgetreten
---------------------------
'ssh-agent' ist fehlgeschlagen mit Code -1: System.Exception: Unable to to start 'C:\Users\administrator\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\git_local\bin\ssh-agent.exe' check the git installation.
 ()
---------------------------
OK   
---------------------------
If I look in the folder C:\Users\administrator\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\git_local\bin\ there's no ssh-agent.exe.

Workaround:
I converted my OpenSSH key with the Putty Key Generator into a Putty keypair. Then the error is gone.
fields.summary: OpenSSH: Fresh SourceTree Installation shows an error "Unable to to start ssh-agent.exe"

fields.description: At least in Mercurial, all branches are rendered the same. It would be great to distinguish regular, active branches from inactive and closed branches.
fields.summary: Make closed branches and inactive branches look different from active branches

fields.description: At least in Mercurial, it is currently not possible to hide the closed branches in the list of branches.
fields.summary: Make it possible to hide closed branches

fields.description:
After upgrading to 1.6.23, the button "Terminal" doesn't open git bash anymore, but ends in an error message of:

_It has not been possible to start the Git Bash terminal._

My settings:
* v1.6.23 of SourceTree for Windows
* Checked _Use Git Bash as default terminal_ (it works when just opening cmd.exe)
* I use System git. Previously 1.9.x, but now I upgraded to 2.6.3, still the same problem. I didn't try the embedded git.
fields.summary: Git Bash button doesn't work

fields.description:
If using a version number format as a tag, then the order is not correct.

As per the screenwhot, you can see how v6.11.2, appears above v6.3.5, or how v5.14.3 appears above v5.4.0
fields.summary: Tags do not order properly

fields.description:
h2.Current state
When doing code reviews (without any additional tools) I search for commits using the Jira issue number (we always commit in a way we can find the stuff build for a certain story). 
Then, I am able to select only a single changeset at the time and view the file changes within.

I am able to view multiple changes on a single file though, but that requires that I run through all the changesets and remember which files I already looked at.

h2. Preferred state
As a developer/code reviewer I want to be able to search for changesets and then select the ones I am interested in, while all the changes are "merged" into a single view in the commit details so I can view all the changes in one go. The view should be strictly readonly and requires only the functionality that already exists in the *Log Selected* feature.

In case there are multiple changes from different stories, that are not in my search results, it is acceptable to see them too, as long as they are marked as 3rd party changes (e.g. gray or blue or any other color).
fields.summary: Merged view of multiple commits

fields.description:
Automatic merges have the same time, so commits must be sorted carefully. Otherwise child may be placed in the tree before parent and this leads to broken tree.

Commit ec008f1 must be placed after commit 772a317 because 772a317 is a parent of ec008f1. See image for details.
fields.summary: Tree view is broken in case of automatic merge

fields.description: Source Tree won't start. Please see log file
fields.summary: The settings property 'AnalyticsGatewayAnalyticsServerUrl' was not found.

fields.description: In local branches, anytime I right click on a branch and select "Create Pull Request..." SourceTree immediately crashes. This may have coincided with a Java version update.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when creating pull request

fields.description:
When I hit the Terminal button I get an error message:

It has not been possible to start the Git Bash terminal.
fields.summary: Terminal cannot open BASH window

fields.description:
After updating SourceTree to the latest version (1.6.23.0), I can't open Terminal with Git Bash. However, I still can use Terminal with Windows default Command Prompt (unchecking Use Git Bash as Default Terminal in Git Options).

I have never encountered this error before, so I think this is a bug in the latest version.
fields.summary: Error While Opening Terminal With Git Bash In SourceTree

fields.description:
After SourceTree updated to 1.6.23 'Terminal' button doesn't work anymore.

{code}
Current directory:
C:\dev\project

Command to be executed:

{code}

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to mark hunks and entire files as "noncommitable".  There are many times where I turn debug flags on in code and want to make sure that the changes aren't in my final commits.  I still want to see that files in the unstaged files pane, as well as in the diffs for those files, however, I would like them in a color indicating their state and I don't want them selectable using the select all checkbox.

Currently, I can sort of achieve this on the file level using
git update-index --assume-unchanged
and
git update-index --no-assume-unchanged
but the downside with that is that it doesn't work at the hunk level and the files don't show up in the modified file list.
fields.summary: Allow user to mark hunks/files as "noncommitable"

E.g. see 1-InitialScroll.png for this initial bad state.
If I scroll up and then back down those displayed paths usually change to some other random set.
When I do an explicit refresh (F5) the paths are shown correctly (no path in this example, as these files are at the root of the repos). See 2-AfterRefresh.png.
Restarting sourcetree doesn't help.
My file list view is Pending files sorted by status, with Flat list multi column, split view staging. This is happening in the Unstaged files area, haven't checked Staged.

fields.description:
I often base new projects off of skeleton projects by using an extra remote to use to pull the base copy and future improvements if necessary. The new project gets a new version number and that gets a tag. The problem is that all of the tags from the previous versions of the base project are still around and clobber the tag namespace.

Git has an option to take care of this issue: `git remote add --no-tags base /path/to/base.repo.git`. I however cannot find a way to do this in SourceTree without manually opening the repo's config and adding `tagopt = --no-tags` to `[remote "base"]`. I'd like there to be a simple way to change this setting for each remote.
fields.summary: Add remotes with --no-tags option

fields.description:
Some firewalls blacklist HTTP/HTTPS requests when the request does not include a user-agent string. When SourceTree attempts to log into github (eg Clone/New -> browse hosted projects), the requests to api.github.com:443 fail. The full header is below.

CONNECT api.github.com:443 HTTP/1.1
Proxy-Authorization: Negotiate [redacted]
Host: api.github.com
Proxy-Connection: Keep-Alive

Additionally, our corporate firewall gives a 200 OK response with an error page indicating that user-agent filtering is blocking this request, but sourcetree does not handle this response in a meaningful way; instead, it repeats the request (which fails) and alerts a Login error dialog box with the message:

"Login failed for your GitHub account.

The remote service said: 'The underlying connection was closed: An unexpected error occurred on a send.'"
fields.summary: SourceTree does not send user-agent strings in HTTP requests

fields.description:
*STR:*
# Prepare a remote Git repo that has two branches: `master` and `foo`, where the two branches have diverged slightly (eg master is two commits ahead)
# Open SourceTree
# Clone that remote Git repo locally
# Whilst on the `master` branch, use the branch feature to create a new branch called `bar`
# In the list of branches on the sidebar, right click the branch `bar`, and under the "Track remote branch" submenu, choose `origin/foo`
# Note the status icon shown next to `bar` in the sidebar
# Press the "Push" icon on the SourceTree toolbar
# Note the value shown under "Remote Branch" on the row for `bar`

*Expected:*
The push window shows the remote branch for `bar` to be the `foo` branch. 

*Actual:*
The push window shows the remote branch for `bar` to be the `bar` branch, which doesn't actually exist on the remote. Ticking the `push` box on the `bar` row will then create a new remote rather than updating the existing one.

This is surprising, since at step [6] the status icon shows there are two new commits to push, so to me that implies the push dialog will push them.

This has caused me to create new branches my accident (and not realise I wasn't updating the existing one), causing confusion when debugging issues.
fields.summary: The "push" window doesn't honour the "track remote branch" setting

fields.description: When using SourceTree file view with Java programs with the default encoding cp1252, some characters are not supported.
fields.summary: Default text encoding support for cp1252

fields.description:
SourceTree for Windows does not fully honor git's gitignore pattern format. You can observe the problem by using the git shell for Windows side-by-side with Sourcetree.

See attached tree.PNG for the example folder structure.

See attached gitshell.PNG for how git shell for Windows sees the working directory. Note that I added all non-.gitignored files as seen by git shell using git status.

See attached sourcetree.PNG for how Sourcetree sees the working directory. Note the unstaged files that should be ignored if Sourcetree is behaving the same as git shell for Windows.

See attached .gitignore for the actual .gitignore file from the working directory.

Refer to the 'PATTERN FORMAT' section of http://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore. Specifically:

{noformat}A leading ** followed by a slash means match in all directories. For example, **/foo matches file or directory foo anywhere.{noformat}

{noformat}A trailing /** matches everything inside. For example, abc/** matches all files inside directory abc, relative to the location of the .gitignore file, with infinite depth.{noformat}

In this case, all of the unstaged files from sourcetree.PNG should be ignored under one or both of the rules above.
fields.summary: not honoring complex gitignore patterns with two consecutive asterisks

fields.description:
Not every time, but quite often, I get this fatal error when trying to switch branches in my repository:
 
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false checkout <branch-name>
fatal: Unable to create 'D:/Evi/Source/Git/.git/index.lock': File exists.
If no other git process is currently running, this probably means a
git process crashed in this repository earlier. Make sure no other git
process is running and remove the file manually to continue.
 
I think the problems started after I updated the Git-for-Windows version from 1.9.5 to 2.5.x and prevailed in 2.6.x. Restarting SourceTree solves the issue (temporarily). I noticed that the latest SourceTree version 1.6.22.0 still downloads the 1.9.5 preview version when I try switching to  Embedded Git.

So, is this an incompatibility issue of SourceTree with Git-for-Windows 2.x? A Fix really would be appreciated since having to restart SourceTree gets quite annoying. The issue exists on multiple machines in our company.
fields.summary: fatal: Unable to create 'D:/Evi/Source/Git/.git/index.lock': File exists
